lines.text: People who live in glass houses shouldn't live in glass houses.
I'm glad you're here Donnie. I have a bone to pick with you.
Oh, well, let's pick it over there, under the piano.
Very well.
I guess I'm too - pure. Well, nothing I can do about that. I wonder...
Well, dear, what does interests young men nowadays?
If I knew the answer to that, darling, I wouldn't be sitting here all wrapped up in gloom.
All the pleasure of dancing with a lovely young lady and none of the hazards.
Oh, Mr. Patridge, you can be a little hazardous.
Who's that girl?
Which one?
The one in white over there, wasting that gorgeous smile on old man Patridge.
Oh, that's Venice Muir.
Well, I'm cutting in.
Go ahead. She's a nice girl. Nicest girl I know. Old Patridge is her lawyer. You know, custody of her estate. He said he used to take her over his knee and spank her, et cetera.
Well, he can be her lawyer or trustee, I'll, eh, take the et cetera.
She's too gloomy.
Oh, she is not. Why, Venice is the sweetest girl here. She has a positively beautiful sense of humor. And, underneath, why, she's really warm - and vibrant - and mysterious.
Venice?
Yes, Venice. And she isn't shop-worn!
Someday a man with a nose for adventure is going to come along - and - discover Venice. And you can just bet that he'll have the most exciting time of any man in New York.
I love your sense of humor; but, don't use it just now.
You look like a - good girl.
Oh, do I?
You are a good girl, aren't you?
Yes, I'm afraid that may be my trouble.
Would you like to earn some money?
I'll do anything short of murder.
Well, would you work for me?
Well, sure, why not?
Well, I know this, eh, funny thing to ask anyone, but, I was wondering, could you be a, sort of, well, eh, sort of, a gigolo?
I spent an hour at the Ritz bar after I left you. Oh, lady, lady, when I left there, a lot of the fellas said that you were simply wonderful! You had everything! Even a very, eh, a very slight past.
Past?
Oh, nothing you could put your finger on. But, a lot of the boys will try.
Oh, I'll die. I couldn't live up to the past of a midget!
You don't know midgets. Now, I heard of a midget that broke up the home of a heavy weight champ.
We're bound to met some fellas here.
Oh, Guy, I'm scared.
Oh, come along. So was Eve and look what a mess she made of Adam.
Oh, I know; but, I don't want to make a mess of anyone.
I know, my pet, they never want to.
Courage, my pet. Courage.
Good night, Guy. You're a perfect gigolo.
When did you get the idea you say good night to a gigolo?
Why, what do you mean?
Get up. I hate to see a woman on her knees, unless, she''s scrubbing.
Come along, come along. I want to give you a practical lesson in what used to be called sin.
Good night, Venice. You're swell. Everything's gonna work out all right.
Thanks. You are a perfect gigolo. I almost feel like kissing you!
What could I do? I'd have to stand it.

[Jokingly]
You're horrid!
I still think the bicycle races are more interesting than the polo match.
The trouble with you Argentines is a lack of confidence. That's why you lost the war.
What war?
I don't know, any war. What war were you in?
Well, I guess the only place I could talk to you would be while you're taking a bath.
Say you've got lovely hair. Where did you get it?
I've had it for years.
You seem unusually gay tonight, Rene, and rightfully so. It's a lovely party.
What's the matter, Rene? A few moments ago you seemed gay!
Don't throw away your red flannel underwear the minute I get off this boat.

[Repeated line]
Goodbye, my pet.
You shouldn't have done that.
No, Donnie, I shouldn't have.
Oh, why not lay off me till I get my perspective back. And, if you're still interested, we might be - playmates. Well, you won't be lonesome in the meantime.
What are you saying?
Oh, don't suddenly go innocent on me!
Are we really going to the bicycle races?
Let's go on a crying drunk. No, no, I can't tonight. I've got to go to the bicycle races.
What do you think about the bicycle races?
Bi-cycle races are idiotic.
What's so idiotic about 'em?
They don't get any where.
I suppose polo players do?
Certainly, to the goal post.
Well, bicycle races get to the finish.
The finish is the start.
Well, nevertheless, we're going to the bi-cycle races.
I hope we don't meet any more men in here, Guy. My ankle won't stand it!
I'm sorry, Venice.
Couldn't you find somewhere else to kick me, for a change?
Well, I could, but it wouldn't be refined.
Oh, Guy!
We're going to the bicycle races, aren't we?
Well, they only started tonight. You have all week to get there.
We may need it.
What am I supposed to do to earn this money?
Well, that's a little awkward to explain.
Well, I'll understand. I've read what every young man should know.
I haven't.
We're going to the bicycle races in a few minutes.
I'll teach you, my pet.
I think anything might be possible with you.
I've simply got to stop talking to myself. I talk to myself so much I'm worn out when I meet people.
Oh, Guy, you're so clever. How is it possible for one human being to know so much?
I should know. I've had two wives... shot out from underneath me.
